data.text: GaiaGPS for planning and navigation. I also use Google Earth some for planning. I have an old 1st gen iPhone SE I use as a dedicated navigation device. It doesn't have a SIM card but I can download maps and upgrades with wifi. If I am not recording a track I can get almost 2 days on a single charge.

data.text: Graph theory, variants of Dijkstra's Algorithm, Bidirectional A*, Bellman-Ford, Contraction Hierarchies, Landmark (ALT), etc.
data.author: Seth Alan Woolley

data.text: This is the correct answer.
data.author: Robert Franklin

data.text: Most everybody else is mentioning brand names that use graph theoretic algorithms such as the mentioned. OSM OpenCycleMap is a free data source for the algorithms, but many brands have or are developing data sources to "improve" their routing results as well. Unfortunately I'm not aware of a really good universal bike router software. They all have pros and cons. In the comments I'd like to see comments on the types of riding and regions where they find success with each application.
data.author: Seth Alan Woolley

data.author: Robert Scott

data.text: OSMand for Nav on an android 4.3 4" phone....still runs. beauty is it has swappable batteries which I have 4 of. If I leave the screen off and let the voice guide me it runs all day. For route planning I use a combination of things. Maplocs, RIdeswithgps, Strava, and believe it or not, I still have old Delorme Topo desktop software which is freakin awesome. It's not so old the roads are out of date, especially the ones I'm riding. I use it for orintable maps. makes (and I'm not sure if anyone here is old enough to remember these) AAA style Trip_Tick maps for my route. I print them on waterproof paper and then even if my NAV phone, my real phone and my Garmin InReach die or GPS is crippled or I just need to see the lay of the land because it's easier to read a paper map (It is for me), I can pull out the paper maps and figure things out.
data.author: Justin Serpico

data.text: Google maps!! I had a wahoo gps with me and I had Strava, ride w/gps, and ride spot all on it. With how fluid my plans were on your, I found G-maps in bicycle mode to be wonderful 98% of the time. Does a great job of routing you away from heavy traffic and towards bike friendly areas or bike paths. It may not always give you the most efficient route, but the turn by turn navigation was great. I have a buckshot 2.0 wireless speaker (waterproof,small and directional) for hikers and bikers. My music would always pause briefly for Google maps to tell me where the next turn is.
data.author: Adam Nguyen

data.text: Komoot + Garmin 1030.
data.author: Graham Bullman
